Outbreak of Spanish-American War

Effects of technology on worker production begin registering powerful effect--up nearly a factor of 4 from .363 cubic feet of quarried stone per man hour in 1881 to 1.31 for every hour by 1895. Total employment in stone industry triples.

Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: U.S. Supreme Court hands down Dred Scott case ruling that African Americans have 'no rights that whites are bound to respect' and are not citizens under law. It also rules that congress has no power to prohibit slavery in the territories.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: By December, Indiana supplies 61,000 volunteers, exceeding its quota of 39,000.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Proslavery Kansas Constitution vote prevails when anti-slavery supporters refuse to vote
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: U.S. Senate votes to accept Lecompton Constitution for Kansas; House votes to resubmit the matter to a vote.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: English Bill passes Congress to achieve compromise on Kansas
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Abraham Lincoln and Stephen A. Douglas hold a series of debates in Illinois while vying for a U.S. Senate seat. Slavery dominates their arguments
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Resubmission of Lecompton Constitution to Kansas voters, who reject it. Kansas will remain a territory until 1861.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Whig Zachary Taylor becomes president; Lewis Cass carries Indiana with 49 percent of votes, while Free Soil nominee Martin Van Buren collects 5 percent of votes
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: After trial for murder in Kansas, John Brown hangs.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: A group of Indiana African Americans meets in Indianapolis to appeal to Indiana General Assembly to rescind restrictions on testimony in state courts
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: The new Indiana People's Party wins large majorities in various Indiana elections, sweeps state offices, wins nine of eleven congressional seats, and gains control of state House of Representatives
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Republican national convention in Chicago, Illinois, nominates Abraham Lincoln for president
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: The Whig Party and American Party form the Constitutional Union Party, nominating John Bell for President
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Southern Democrats nominate John C. Breckinridge for president. Indiana senators Jesse D. Bright and Graham N. Fitch support Breckinridge's ticket
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Nomination of Stephen A. Douglas for president; reconvention of Democratic Party convention in Baltimore where Southern delegates walk out again
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Republican Party candidate Henry S. Lane becomes governor over Democrat Hendricks. Republicans retain seven congressional seats and regain control of both houses of the General Assembly
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Presentation of Wilmot Proviso states the prohibition of slavery in territory formerly belonging to Mexico, a wedge forms between Northern and Southern Democrats
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Abraham Lincoln becomes president, taking a majority of the Indiana vote.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Radical anti-slavery leader John Brown leads violent raid on U.S. arsenal at Harpers Ferry, Virginia, in an attempt to foment slave insurrection. U.S. troops overcome raiders.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Approval of new Indiana state constitution; article in constitution excluding African Americans and providing funds to send African Americans to Liberia is given to voters, voters approve of this article.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Senator Stephen A. Douglas of Illinois introduces Kansas-Nebraska bill to admit those territories to statehood by popular sovereignty. Bill passes in May. Anti-slavery democrats leave Democratic Party in protest over Kansas-Nebraska Act.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Large temperance convention held in Indianapolis
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: A free slave from Georgia, by the name of John Freeman, moves to Indiana and ends up in jail when a man claims that Freeman is his runaway slave. The court case disproves this claim and creates a stir throughout the state against fugitive slave law
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Indiana Free Soil Party forms the Free Democratic Association
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Democratic Party candidate Franklin Pierce becomes President, carrying Indiana with 52 percent of the vote; Free Soil Party gains less than 4 percent with Hoosier Julian on the ticket.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Democrat Joseph A. Wright becomes governor. Democrats nearly sweep congressional races, except for the Whigs winning one seat, and gain control of the General Assembly
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Free Soil Party nominates U.S. Representative George W. Julian of Centreville, Indiana, as vice presidential candidate
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Brief_Description: First Know Nothing lodge is formed
Entry.Event: Formation of First Know Nothing lodge in Lawrenceburg following collapse of Whig Party and amid rise of anti-Catholicism in Indiana
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Formation of Free Soil Party, calling for the territories to be free from slavery
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Indiana General Assembly legislate law to require local governments to establish separate schools for African American children if there is a sufficient number of children to justify it
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Democratic national convention in Charleston, South Carolina breaks up when Southern delegates walk out in protest of insufficiently forceful protection of slavery
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Anti-slavery settlers in Kansas repudiate fraudulent pro-slavery territorial legislature.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: A new government is set up by anti-slavery settlers in Kansas; there are now two governments in Kansas
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: A group of Indiana women form a Women's Rights Association in Dublin, Wayne County, demanding rights for women
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Maine enacts statewide prohibition on sale of alcoholic beverages.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: South Carolina Congressman Preston Brooks severely beats Massachusetts Senator Charles Sumner on Senate floor, requiring three years of recovery for wounds
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Democrat Ashbel P. Wilford becomes governor, narrowly defeating People's Party candidate Oliver P. Morton. Democrats win state offices, regain four congressional seats and control of the lower house of the General Assembly, but a coalition of the People'
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Introduction of Compromise Legislation by Henry Clay to Congress. Legislation works out sectional conflict over slavery. Congress passes legislation and President Millard Fillmore signs it.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Democratic Party Candidate James Buchanan becomes president over Republican candidate John C. Fremont with over 50 percent vote in Indiana
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Lecompton Constitutional Convention meets in Kansas, producing a proslavery referendum process
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: South Carolina troops bombard Fort Sumter in Charleston harbor, garrisons surrender
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: General Assembly reorganizes state militia as Indiana Legion, authorizing six additional regiments for twelve months' service
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Lincoln requests four Indiana regiments for three years or duration of war
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Battle of Phillippi, (western) Virginia, Federal victory; Indiana brigadier general Thomas A. Morris commands troops
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Battle of Bull Run, Virginia; rebels are victorious.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: US declares war against Mexico
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Lincoln calls for 75,000 volunteers for three months. Indiana raises 6,000 volunteers, who assemble and organize in Indianapolis
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Indiana General Assembly convenes in special session, authorizing war loan of two million dollars for military appropriations
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Three-month volunteers depart for western Virginia
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Governor Morton appeals to patriotic women of Indiana to supply clothing and blankets for troops
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Governor Oliver P. Morton visits Washington to obtain arms for state militia.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Secession of Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, and Louisiana from the United States. U.S. forts and arsenals in the South are taken
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Proposition to compromise measures to settle sectional issues over slavery by Senator J.J. Crittenden of Kentucky
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Henry S. Lane sworn in as governor and Oliver P. Morton as lieutenant governor. Indiana General Assembly selects Lane as U.S. senator, Morton becomes Governor
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Former democratic governor Joseph A. Wright returns from Europe and endorses Lincoln's war policy
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Indiana General Assembly votes to adopt Fifteenth Amendment to U.S. Constitution giving vote to African American men.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Washington peace conference from February to March
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Confederate forces seize Columbus, Kentucky, violating Kentucky's 'neutrality.' Federal forces enter Kentucky
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: While en route to Washington, D.C., Abraham Lincoln stops to speak in Indianapolis
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: Establishment of Confederate States of America, Jefferson Davis becomes provisional president. Secession of Texas
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Nation, Richard F, and Stephen E. Towne. Indiana's War: The Civil War in Documents. Athens: Ohio University Press, 2009. Print.

Entry.Event: James Robinson, 46, is fatally mangled when crushed under a 18,000 lb piece of falling stone.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Coroner's Inquest; Bloomington Daily Telephone 7 August, 1917 p 2 col 7

Entry.Event: Many African-American citizens of Bloomington sign a petition to prohibit showing the film, The Nigger, at the Princess Theatre. The film is shown nevertheless, with several newspaper accounts of pro and con views of the film regarding its effect on race
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: The Nigger is Protested!' Bloomington Telephone 11 Aug. 1915:1. Microform
Entry.Comment: Also documented in Ehman, Lee. The Racial Divide in 1915 Bloomington. Monroe County Historian Feb. 2011: 5;-8. Print.

Entry.Event: Strike of stone cutters lasted almost two months. Other classes, being organized, held sympathy strike. Settled with small raise.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Wylie, David Gray. 'The Limestone Industry of Indiana,' unpublished masters thesis, Indiana University, 1923, p. 61.
Entry.Comment: IU Library H2 10 .W987.

Entry.Event: Industry-wide strike of all Monroe & Lawrence County companies by 1,500 in nearly all trades. Settled after 3 weeks. Ended on January 21th.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Herald-Telephone 7-1-1970 and other papers to 7-21-1970
Entry.Comment: Found in MCPL vertical file 'Limestone Industry - Strikes'

Entry.Event: Horace Kearney, early aviator, flies his airplane in Dunn Meadow for the first flight ever in Monroe County. He snags a barbed wire fence while taking off, and only gains enough altitude to crash land without life-threatening injuries. Thousands attend th
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Kearney Falls But Will Live' Bloomington Telephone 11 Oct 1915:1. Microform

Entry.Event: Strike began in June. Most locals settled after a few weeks; Victor-Oolitic workers struck until late October.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Indianapolis Star 22 October, 1976
Entry.Comment: Found in MCPL vertical file 'Limestone Industry - Strikes'

Entry.Event: The 52nd Indiana Volunteer Regiment, James M. Smith commanding, is mustered into service in Rushville. Companies B & E includes Monroe County volunteers. They were later consolidated with the 52nd. They fight in the west, including Kentucky, Tennessee, Ar
Entry.Controlled_Vocabulary: United States. Army. Indiana Infantry Regiment, 52nd (1862-1865). Company B & E
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Rose, Melissa. Indiana and the Civil War. Mooresville, IN: Mooresville Park & Recreation District, 1994. P 20.

Entry.Event: Industry-wide strike of all Monroe & Lawrence County companies by 1,250 in nearly all trades. Settled after about 4 weeks. Ended on January 31st.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Courier-Tribune 7-11-1973 and other papers to 7-31-1973
Entry.Comment: Found in MCPL vertical file 'Limestone Industry - Strikes'

Entry.Event: Judge Eckles of Greencastle, Indiana, addresses at the court house, a large meeting of persons against the war. He urges cessation of the conflict, and blames it on the Republican party and Abolitionists. He justifies slavery. Several fights break out dur
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Blanchard, Charles, ed. Counties of Morgan, Monroe, and Brown, Indiana. Historical and Biographical. Chicago: F.A. Battey & Co, 1884. P. 426.

Entry.Brief_Description: Relief Society sends material to camps
Entry.Event: To aid county Civil War soldiers, the Bloomington Relief Society, Stanford Relief Society, and the Female Seminary, sends clothing, food, and hospital stores.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Entire county joined in Civil War relief. Bloomington Herald Telephone. 24 Sept. 1963:XI 4.

Entry.Event: Union supporters listen to speeches and pass resolutions in favor of the war and denouncing the disloyal elements among the population. A week later a similar meeting is held.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Blanchard, Charles, ed. Counties of Morgan, Monroe, and Brown, Indiana. Historical and Biographical. Chicago: F.A. Battey & Co, 1884. P. 427.

Entry.Event: Oolitic Quarry Workers Local of Laborers International Union held brief wildcat strike over installation of new wire sawing units which might cause job losses.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Herald-Telephone 8-17-1968; Tribune & Star-Courier 8-18-1968
Entry.Comment: Found in MCPL vertical file 'Limestone Industry - Strikes'

Entry.Event: When a Monon train, full of Confederate soldier prisoners, arrives at the Bloomington station, pro-southern Butternuts board the train and urge them to escape. All prisoners turn down the anti-Union protesters.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Many in Monroe County have come from South. Bloomington Herald Telephone, 24 Sept. 1968: Sect. XI 6. Microform.

Entry.Event: Before flooding Monroe Lake, The Army Corps of Engineers completed relocation of eight Salt Creek and Polk Twp. cemeteries to the Polk Twp. Cemetery. Graves and markers for the eight relocated cemeteries were arranged so as to retain their original spatia
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Final Report of Cemetery Relocation, Cemetery Relocation Plan No. 1 for Eight Cemeteries, Monroe County, Indiana. Washington, D.C.: U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, 1965: 1-11. Print.

Entry.Event: The 1910 U.S. Census Bureau identified a spot in Monroe County as the population center of the country. Astronomy professor W.A. Cogshall of I.U. first placed the spot in Salt Creek Twp., but later recomputed it to be on the Showers factory grounds.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Population Center in City' Bloomington Daily Telephone 31 Aug. 1911: 1
Entry.Comment: Also documented in Ehman, Lee. Monroe Countys Moving 1910 Population Center Marker. Monroe County Historian Dec. 2010: 6-7. Print.

Entry.Event: Whitecappers, a vigilante group devoted to regulating their version of moral behavior, give Harvey McFarland a severe beating. They are charged with felonies, and in 1912 convicted and imprisoned, through the efforts of Governor Marshall. It is the first
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: 7 Alleged Whitecappers; Prominent Men Charged with McFarland Regulating: Victim Tells Dramatic Story to the Telephone.' Bloomington Daily Telephone 8 May 1911: 1. Microform.
Entry.Comment: Also documented in Ehman, Lee. Vigilante Justice: Whitecapping in Monroe County. Monroe County Historian forthcoming. Print.

Entry.Event: James Myers, 35, falls fatally from the quarry edge at the Matthews Stone Mill of Ellettsville, fracturing skull and bones on right side.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Coroner's Inquest; Bloomington Daily Telephone 16 March, 1909 p 1 col 4

Entry.Event: Strike began on July 2; involved 7 companies and 8 unions. Settled by all but one union on July 18 when work resumed.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Herald-Telephone 6-2-1979 and other papers to 7-18-1979
Entry.Comment: Found in MCPL vertical file 'Limestone Industry - Strikes'

Entry.Event: The 20th Regiment of Indiana Militia is organized, with John Storm commissioned Colonel. They are kept ready for outbreaks of violence by Indians. John Ketchum succeeds Storm as colonel in 1822.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Blanchard, Charles, ed. Counties of Morgan, Monroe, and Brown, Indiana. Historical and Biographical. Chicago: F.A. Battey & Co, 1884. P. 413

Entry.Brief_Description: Principal and teachers resign in protest
Entry.Event: Howard H. Clark, principal of Bloomington H.S., and eight of his teachers, resign in protest over school board actions. Their resignations were accepted, school is suspended for three weeks, and a series of citizens meetings resulted in resignation of th
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: High School Teachers Resign in a Body. Bloomington Evening World 15 Mar 1907: 1. Microform.
Entry.Comment: Also documented in Ehman, Lee. Citizen Involvement in Bloomington School Politics. Monroe County Historian forthcoming. Print.

Entry.Event: Joseph Jones, superintendent of the Bedford quarry for Acme Stone Company, dies of heart failure.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Evening World 28 November, 1905 p 1 col 1

Entry.Event: The New Albany & Salem Railroad (later the Monon) is completed to Bloomington. It connects New Albany to the county for the first time. It also connects to the Vandalia Railroad, which gave access in all directions.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Hendricks, Cecilia Hennel. University Weathers Civil War Crisis. A & S The Review. Indiana University, November, 1960. P. 23.
Entry.Comment: Also Thornbrough, Emma Lou. Indiana in the Civil War Era, 1850-1880. Vol. 3. Indianapolis: Indiana Historical Bureau & Historical Society, 1965. Pp. 506-07.

Entry.Event: Richard B. McCorkle, living in Monroe County, emancipates a slave named Michael, whom had been willed to McCorkle by his father, living in Tennessee at the time. Michael is 22 years old, and accompanies McCorkle to Illinois in 1831.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Monroe County Deed Record, Book C., p. 179
Entry.Comment: Also documented in Ehman, Lee. Michaels 1830 Emancipation. Monroe County Historian Feb. 2004: 1. Print.

Entry.Brief_Description: Company A, 3rd Ind, leaves for war
Entry.Event: Company A, 3rd Indiana Infantry Volunteers, is formed and leaves for the Mexican War. They fight at the battle of Buena Vista.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Blanchard, Charles, ed. Counties of Morgan, Monroe, and Brown, Indiana. Historical and Biographical. Chicago: F.A. Battey & Co, 1884. P. 414.

Entry.Event: Virgil Brown, 39, is killed when his clothing became caught in a line shaft at Mugg Stone Crushing quarry at Quincy, near Spencer.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Telephone 9 December, 1938
Entry.Comment: Coroner's Inquest plus Bl. Tele 12-9-1938 & 12-17-1938

Entry.Event: Louis Cleveland Welch, 51, is fatally crushed by falling stone at the Central Mill of the Shawnee Stone Company.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Telephone 23 February, 1937
Entry.Comment: Coroner's Inquest plus Bl Tele 2-23-1937 & 2-24-1937

Entry.Event: The sole surviving Monroe County veteran, William Meadows, dies at age 96. Meadows is from the Mt. Ebal neighborhood. He served in the 16th Indian Infantry Volunteers, and was wounded at Richmond, Kentucky, in 1862, carrying with him Confederate bullets t
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Wm. Meadows last of Monroe County Civil War vets, dies. Bloomington Daily Telephone. 17 May 1943:1. Microform.

Entry.Event: The 65th Indiana Volunteer Regiment, John W. Foster commanding, is mustered into service in Evansville. Company A includes Monroe County volunteers. They fight in the battles of Atlanta and Wilmington.
Entry.Controlled_Vocabulary: United States. Army. Indiana Infantry Regiment, 65th Company A
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Rose, Melissa. Indiana and the Civil War. Mooresville, IN: Mooresville Park & Recreation District, 1994. P 20.

Entry.Event: Jesse N. Fender, 24, is killed by a falling boom pole while working as a hooker at the Johnson Stone Co.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Coroner's Inquest; Bloomington Evening World 11 November, 1905 p 1 col 1
Entry.Comment: Listed as James in the newspaper.

Entry.Event: Limestone Institute offers same pay scale to crafts; craft union asks for pay increases from .25 to .46/hr.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Weekly Herald 26 January, 1949
Entry.Comment: Found in MCHC Genealogy Library vertical file 'Limestone Industry - General'

Entry.Event: Journeymen Stone Cutters strike; asked for 10% increase
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Daily Herald-Telephone ~3 16, 1951
Entry.Comment: Found in MCHC Genealogy Library vertical file 'Limestone Industry - General'

Entry.Event: John W. Young, 65, dies of a heart attack at the Monon Stone Company, southwest of Clear Creek.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Evening World 16 June, 1936
Entry.Comment: See all: Coroner's Inquest plus Bl Tele 6-16-1936 & Eve Wld 6-16-1936

Entry.Event: The first Indiana University degrees were conferred.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Thornbrough, Emma Lou. Indiana in the Civil War Era, 1850-1880. Vol. 3. Indianapolis: Indiana Historical Bureau & Historical Society, 1965. P. 506.

Entry.Event: An Indiana University student, W.C.L. Taylor, is an amphibious soldier aboard the Union navy ironclad Monitor when it engages the Confederate ironclad Merrimac in Hampton Roads, off the Virginia coast.
Entry.Controlled_Vocabulary: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Indiana University
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Clark, Thomas D. Indiana University: Midwestern Pioneer. Vol. 1. The Early Years. Bloomington, IN: Indiana University Press, 1970. P. 107.

Entry.Brief_Description: Company G, 4th Ind, leaves for war
Entry.Event: Company G, 4th Indiana Infantry Volunteers, is formed and leaves for the war. It participates in battles during General Scotts march from Vera Cruz to Mexico City.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Blanchard, Charles, ed. Counties of Morgan, Monroe, and Brown, Indiana. Historical and Biographical. Chicago: F.A. Battey & Co, 1884. P. 414.

Entry.Event: Two-day strike of 19 blacksmiths concluded with .50/hr pay raise; 1,500 other crafts in sympathy strike.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Herald-Telephone 8-10-1966 plus several other articles from multiple papers spanning 6 17-Aug 10
Entry.Comment: Found in MCPL vertical file 'Limestone Industry - Strikes'

Entry.Event: David Van Buskirk of Bean Blossom Twp, the tallest man in the Union army, joined Company F, 27th Indiana Volunteers. He was captured during the battle of Winchester. He was taken to Libby prison, where Confederate president Jefferson Davis came to see him
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Datzman, Richard C. The Tallest Union Soldier in the Civil War. Indiana History Bulletin, March 1974. Pp. 32-36.

Entry.Event: Stonecutters, planer men and carvers of Journeyman's Stonecutters Association of Monroe Co. agree to 2-year contract.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Bloomington Daily Herald-Telephone 7-30-1960
Entry.Comment: Found in MCHC Genealogy Library vertical file 'Limestone Industry - General'

Entry.Event: The 97th Indiana Volunteer Regiment, R.F. Catterson commanding, is mustered into service in Madison. Companies C, E & G includes Monroe County volunteers. They fight in the battles of Vicksburg, Chattanooga, Atlanta, and Shermans March.
Entry.Controlled_Vocabulary: United States. Army. Indiana Infantry Regiment, 97th Company C, E & G
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Rose, Melissa. Indiana and the Civil War. Mooresville, IN: Mooresville Park & Recreation District, 1994. P 21.

Entry.Event: Six-weeks strike

Entry.Event: After news of President Lincolns death, Bloomington churches hold memorial services, and a large crowd assembles at the court house to honor his memory. Former Governor Dunning, I.U. President Nutt, and others, gave memorials.

Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Civil War feelings ran high in Monroe County. Bloomington Herald Telephone, 17 Mar. 1997: C1. Microform.

Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Clark, Thomas D. Indiana University: Midwestern Pioneer. Vol. 1. The Early Years. Bloomington, IN: Indiana University Press, 1970. Pp. 104-5.

Entry.Event: The one Indiana University building, including the library, burns and is completely destroyed. The citizens of Bloomington pledge $10,000, and the state gives a loan of $6,000 plus other allocations, to rebuild. The university reopens for the 1856-57 scho

Entry.Event: The Board of County Commissioners appropriate $1,000 for relief of families of soldiers. Other charitable groups, including the Christian Commission, Ladies Society, and First Methodist Church, carry out fund-raising events for this purpose.

Entry.Event: The 39th Indiana Volunteer Regiment, Thomas J. Harrison commanding, is mustered into service in Indianapolis. Company M includes Monroe County volunteers. The regiment lost 9 officers killed, and 300 were prisoners. They captured 1,500 enemy soldiers.

Entry.Event: Wallace Hight, who supervises its manufacture at the Seward foundry in Bloomington, takes a brass six-pounder cannon, drawn by six horses, to Indianapolis to be used in the war with the 9th Battery.

Entry.Event: A large mass meeting of Union supporters is held at the court house. Former governor Dunning speaks in favor of pursing the war and urges volunteers, while Judge James Hughes denounced the rebellion.
Entry.Source_Full_Citation: Blanchard, Charles, ed. Counties of Morgan, Monroe, and Brown, Indiana. Historical and Biographical. Chicago: F.A. Battey & Co, 1884. P. 420.
